articles.title: 'WHAT'S NEXT FOR PADDY?!' | UFC 324: GAETHJE vs PIMBLETT AFTERMATH
articles.description: After UFC 324, the big question is simple: what does Paddy Pimblett do next? After a brutal five-round loss to Justin Gaethje, Paddy proved what many doubters questioned ‚Äî his toughness, heart, and refusal to quit at the elite level. But if the goal is still to become UFC champion, changes are needed. From tightening up his striking defense and boxing fundamentals to making a serious investment in wrestling, this breakdown looks at what Paddy did right, what went wrong, and how he evolves from here. With the lightweight rankings taking shape, one matchup stands out above the rest ‚Äî Paddy Pimblett vs Dan Hooker. Ranked back-to-back, real heat, real stakes, and a guaranteed war. Is this the perfect next fight, or am I out of my mind? articles.title: Dana White Eliminates UFC Bonus ‚Äî Explained
articles.description: Dana White just made a major change to the UFC bonus system. The traditional discretionary bonuses ‚Äî where fighters across the card received checks ranging from $5,000 to $25,000 ‚Äî are officially gone. Now, only finishes earn a $25,000 bonus, changing how fighters get rewarded after every event. This move could completely reshape: ‚Ä¢ Fighter incentives ‚Ä¢ Fight strategies ‚Ä¢ Risk-taking in the cage ‚Ä¢ Pay structure across the card üí¨ Is this better for fighters ‚Äî or worse? articles.title: Why Chael Picked Paddy Pimblett to Beat Gaethje
articles.description: Chael Sonnen breaks down why he initially believed Paddy Pimblett would defeat Justin Gaethje, and how fight week completely changed the narrative once the cage door closed. Sonnen explains how Gaethje‚Äôs unusual demeanor throughout fight week‚Äîangrier, more confrontational, and visibly irritated‚Äîsignaled that something different was coming. While Sonnen originally leaned toward Pimblett based on youth, momentum, and grappling upside, Gaethje‚Äôs pressure, conditioning, and control quickly dismantled that expectation. The analysis focuses on Gaethje‚Äôs ability to dictate where fights take place. Using elite anti-wrestling, forward pressure, and relentless pace, Gaethje kept the fight exactly where he wanted it‚Äîon the feet, moving forward, and backing Pimblett up. Sonnen explains why backing up is one of the hardest things for a wrestler to overcome, and how Gaethje‚Äôs pressure neutralized Pimblett‚Äôs offense round after round. Sonnen also addresses the narrative of ‚Äúold‚Äù or ‚Äúvintage‚Äù Gaethje, explaining why this wasn‚Äôt a resurgence at all‚Äîbut simply the same fighter fans have always seen. Gaethje walks opponents down, breaks them over time, and refuses to give ground. Finally, Sonnen looks ahead at what this result means for the lightweight division, including potential future opponents and why the loser of this fight may have ended up in a better position than the winner. articles.title: The One Advantage Justin Gaethje Always Had | UFC 324
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL ! #bruntpochael Chael Sonnen breaks down why the outcome of Justin Gaethje vs. Paddy Pimblett was far more predictable than it appeared heading into fight night. In this analysis, Sonnen explains how press conferences and fight-week behavior are often misunderstood. While most fans watch for entertainment, experienced analysts look for tells‚Äîsubtle indicators of confidence, clarity, and realistic paths to victory. According to Sonnen, both fighters already knew who the better athlete was. The real question was never who would win, but how. Sonnen walks through Pimblett‚Äôs only viable strategy: submission. He then methodically explains why that path required a series of unlikely events‚Äîmultiple takedowns, sustained control, positional advancement, and a finish against one of the best anti-wrestlers in the sport. By contrast, Gaethje‚Äôs path to victory was simple and immediate. The fight begins on the feet, and Gaethje thrives there. The breakdown also explores why submissions at the elite level are often the result of fatigue rather than dominance, and why expecting Gaethje to quit under pressure was unrealistic. Sonnen compares Pimblett‚Äôs challenge to the difficulty elite fighters like Khabib Nurmagomedov and Michael Chandler had keeping Gaethje down. Finally, Sonnen explains why outside influence‚Äîconversations with respected fighters and coaches‚Äîtemporarily shifted his prediction, and how fight week ultimately revealed the truth. This is a masterclass in reading fights before they happen. #UFC #JustinGaethje #PaddyPimblett #MMA #FightAnalysis #ChaelSonnen Bad Guy Inc merch now available at https://BadGuyInc.com Click here to subscribe: https://bit.ly/3FrHIPK Follow me on IG: https://bit.ly/3HY7BIE Follow me on Twitter: https://bit.ly/3tvY5J7 Follow me on Threads https://www.threads.com/@sonnench

articles.title: Chael‚Äôs Honest Take: Suga Sean Lost, BUT‚Ä¶
articles.description: Get $10 Off @BRUNT with code CHAEL at https://bruntworkwear.com/CHAEL ! #bruntpochael Chael Sonnen gives his honest take on the controversial decision between Sean O‚ÄôMalley and Song Yadong, explaining why he personally scored the fight for Song Yadong‚Äîbut why the outcome doesn‚Äôt ultimately change Sean O‚ÄôMalley‚Äôs position in the division. In this breakdown, Sonnen explains why the matchup never fully made sense going in. There was no personal rivalry, no promotional tension, and very little upside for O‚ÄôMalley despite the risk. The crowd reaction, the momentum shifts during the fight, and the uncertainty afterward all reinforced how razor-thin the margin was. Sonnen also addresses why many fans felt Song Yadong did enough to win, and why the decision was met with immediate pushback inside the arena. He compares this moment to other situations where elite fighters were handed difficult assignments with no obvious reward‚Äîsomething that has become a recurring test at the top of the sport. While Sonnen disagreed with the scorecards, he explains why this fight represented the ask‚Äîthe moment when a champion is expected to accept danger without complaint. O‚ÄôMalley did exactly that, survived a tough opponent, and still walked away with the victory. The question now is simple: what comes next for the UFC bantamweight division? A headline coming out of weigh-ins claimed Patty Pimblett held a size advantage over Justin Gaethje. That claim doesn‚Äôt survive even a basic look at how weight classes actually work. Both fighters weighed in at 155 pounds. That‚Äôs not a suggestion, not a range ‚Äî it‚Äôs a hard number. At that point, size advantages don‚Äôt exist. Lightweight is lightweight. Enough is enough. In this video, Chael Sonnen breaks down why face-off photos and surface-level narratives keep misleading fans during fight week. He explains how gyms actually separate athletes by real size, why fighters within certain ranges are effectively the same weight, and why ‚Äúsize advantage‚Äù headlines often collapse under scrutiny. The conversation also explores the strange incentives created by modern weight cutting, why weigh-ins have become more theatrical than functional, and how post-weigh-in rehydration blurs reality even further. This isn‚Äôt about criticizing fighters or reporters. It‚Äôs about precision. If a claim can‚Äôt hold up to basic logic, it shouldn‚Äôt be repeated ‚Äî no matter how good it sounds in a headline. Ends 1/25/26 at 11:59 PM ET. Sponsored by DK. Why is this fight happening ‚Äî and what does it actually lead to? Cameron Smotherman made weight ‚Äî and then his body gave out. He stepped on the scale at 135.5 pounds, officially cleared the limit, took a few steps, and collapsed moments later. No theatrics. No exaggeration. Just a visible example of what extreme weight cutting can look like when the margin disappears. The moment wasn‚Äôt about the fall itself. It was about the fact that Smotherman still made weight. That detail matters. Whatever misery the cut required, whatever strain it placed on the body, the job was finished before the system failed. That is toughness ‚Äî and it also highlights a problem the sport continues to acknowledge without meaningfully fixing. This issue has been solved before. The NCAA ended extreme weight cutting decades ago, not through discussion panels or medical speculation, but by changing the weigh-in window. When athletes were required to compete shortly after weighing in, dehydration stopped immediately. The incentive disappeared. A weigh-in held a full day before competition is no longer functional. It serves marketing purposes, not competitive ones. Fighters rehydrate, reconstitute, and often enter the cage at drastically different weights than what was measured. Fighters are adults, and they will always pursue advantages within the rules. But there is a cost ‚Äî and this time, that cost was caught on video. The hope is that Smotherman is healthy and recovers fully. The larger hope is that moments like this finally lead to action instead of repetition.
